publisher.orgName: Department of Digital Humanities, University of Graz

authority.orgName: Department of Digital Humanities, University of Graz

seriesStmt.title: GlossIT: Celtic and Latin glossing traditions: uncovering early medieval language contact and knowledge transfer
GlossIT: Keltische und lateinische Glossen als Quellen für frühmittelalterlichen Sprachkontakt und Wissenstransfer

editorialDecl.p: was über die editionsregeln und kodierungsrichtlinien

projectDesc.p: Glosses are fingerprints of the society in which texts were composed, copied, and read. Most importantly, they play a much more significant role than previous research has acknowledged and offer insights about the multilingual and multi-ethnic environment of medieval manuscript and text production the principal texts cannot: they are first-hand testimonies of the close linguistic and cultural connections between Insular Celtic (Old Breton, Old Irish, Old Welsh) and Latin speakers. GLOSSIT researches these contacts combining methods of comparative philology and historical linguistics, digital humanities (handwritten text recognition, network analysis, natural language processing), (cultural) history, and biological computation (applying DNA-sequence alignment methods to glosses).

Quidam autumant ianuariũ ñ cupatum ex eo ꝙ limes et ianua sit anni.-
secundum dicauit februo id ẽ. plutoni qͥ lustrationũ potens credebat᷑. Lustra
riq; eo m̃se ciuitatem necesse erat quo statuit ut iusta diis manibus soluerent᷑.
sed hanc lustrandi consuetudinem bene mutauit xp̃i ana religio. Cum
in m̃se eodem die scæ̃ mariæe plebs uniũsa cũ sacerdotib; ác ministris ymnis
modula deuotis ꝑ eclesias ꝑque congrua urbis loca ꝓcedit; datasq; ápon
tifice cuncti cȩreas in manibus gestant ardentes. Et augescente bona
consuetudine id ipsum incet̃is. q͠q eiꝰdem beatȩ matris et ꝑpetuȩ uirginis
festiuitatib; agere didicit. Ñ utiq; ĩ illustrationem t̃restris imperii
quinquennẽ sed inꝑenem regni cȩlestis memoriam qñ iuxta parabolã
uirginum prudentiũ om̃s electi lucentibus bonoꝝ actuũ lampadib;
obiam sponso ác regi suo uenientes mox cum eo ad nuptias suꝑnȩ
ciuitatis intrabunt; Paulo pͭ numa in honorem in paris numeri unũ
adiecit diem quem ianuario dedit. Ut tã in anno quã in mensibus singulis

h͠c gͦ dinem romanis q͠q imitari placuit. sed frustra. quippe fuit eos diẽ
unum sic̃ supͣ admonuimus additũ e͠e ásé ad grecum numerum in honorem
imparis numeri Ea reꝑoctenniũ conuenire numerus atque ordo non poterat.
sed qui exĩde sit err genitus qualit̃ eidẽ sit succursum inp̃fata chi et p̃
textati disputatione. Uñ et ista decerpsimus qui scire uult inueniet.-
Tandem gaius ilius cessar imitatus egiptios ad numerum solis annum sic̃

div.ab: hodie seruat᷑ instituit .x. uidelicet dies obseruationi uet̃i suꝑadiciens
ut anũ ccclxu dies quib; ipse zodiacum lustrat efficerent. Et né quadrans
de eẽt statuit. Ut quarto q͠q anno sacerdotes qui curauer̃ m̃sib; ac dieb;
unum ĩt̃kalarent d,em. Eo uidelicet m̃se ác loco quo &iam ap̃ uet̃es
mensis ĩt̃kalabatur id est ante .u. ultimos m̃sis februarii dies. id que
bissextũ censuit nominandũ. Om̃i ĩt̃kalationi mensis februarius
deputatus ẽ. qm̃, isultimus anni erat; ꝙ etiã ipsum grecorum dei mi
tatione faciebant.- Nam et illi ultimo anni sui m̃si suꝑ fluos ĩt̃ serebant
dies. Uerum una rẽ á grecis differebant. Nam illi confecto ultimo
m̃se. romani non confecto februario sed pͭ uige. simum & t̃tium diem
ĩt̃kalabant. T̃minalib; scilicet iam ꝑactis; deinde reliquos februarii
m̃sis dies quierant .u. pͭ ĩt̃kalationem subiungebant; Credo ueteri e͠e
religionis suȩ more ut februarium omni modo martius sequeretur..-
